comment.author: 46046969@N03
comment._content: Is that still the current alignment of the road ?

comment.author: 95027075@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/46046969@N03] From Google maps there is a location Soldiers Pinch where it appears an old road veers about 200m to the north of here. It would appear the current road is cut through a hill.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
47201412@N02
comment._content:
The Sydney Morning Herald, Thursday 23 February 1899, p. 6:
MOUNT VICTORIA, Wednesday. ... The road superintendent is considering the desirability of doing away with that steep gradient known as Soldier's Pinch, between here and Blackheath, by deviating to the right just past the recreation ground, and curving out again above the present bridge.
- trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14201246

comment.author: 95027075@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks for that. Modern road building would have made it even easier to change the route. I've been told that the cost of cutting through the sandstone on the Sydney-Newcastle freeway would be a tenth of the cost when it was built.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: GoogleMapsStreetView . The road may have been widened, straightened and levelled since, but I think those are the same buttresses and capstones seen on the streetview (see note).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a stone with old inscriptions a little way up the pass from this photo. Anyone know what it was and what it says? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Much enjoyed your "Westward Ho!" exhibition - I can recommend it to anyone interested.

comment.author: 95027075@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That is interesting, it is the same. It is on the opposite side of Mt Victoria to what is marked as Soldiers Pinch which I assumed was an alternative name to Soldiers Gap. Obviously not, or it is in the wrong place.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Ha! Soldier's Gap / Pinch was a red herring! Good old 4481 keeps keeping us on our toes. ... But now I want to see a real photo of the Pinch!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here's another red herring but a good yarn - the story behind Connolly's rock - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17097732 . Btw the rock underneath on the streetview has a 1832 carved date and what looks like "ELLIS" - ??

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Illustrations from Progress in Public Works & Roads in NSW 1827-1855 / Sir Thomas Mitchell acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=853567&amp... Thumbnail 10. Pass of Victoria when opened [Digital Order No. a1480010] Thumbnail 15. Sketch showing the Soldiers Pinch on the Bathurst Road and the intended line to avoid it [Digital Order No. a1480015]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Good history of the various roads and passes between Mt Victoria and Bathurst, with particular reference to the area of this photo, which it names as "Mitchell's Causeway" or viaduct at Victoria Pass. www.megalongcc.com.au/Ambermere/building_of_the_pass.htm

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
How's this for a theory?  According to the above history, when the railway reached Bathurst (1876) it took away much traffic from this road and it fell into disrepair.  It was repaired in the early 1900s (the "newly completed" date of this photo?) but then early motor vehicles could not cope with the steep hills.  So they built Berghofer's Pass between 1907-12 which was too bendy.  As vehicles improved they went back to the old road, and ever since traffic has been thundering over this old viaduct.  

Thoughts anyone?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
35179849@N08
comment._content: I think this is Victoria Pass on the west side of Mount Victoria.    Soldiers Pinch is on the east side of Mount Victoria between Mt Boyce and  Mt Victoria.  There have been several road alignments there,   but none involving such fancy stonework.    And the end of Mt Boyce is nothing like as rocky as that.   I should know,  I walked down there last Thursday.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
Your description of the Blaxland expedition is seriously lame.   Full of errors that any 8 year old of my generation would spot.
Mount York is not "west of the Cox's River".      They reached Mt York,   and then they went down and crossed the Cox's River  and proceeded to another different mountain,  Mt Blaxland,  which is to the west of Cox's River but still short of the divide.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Thanks for your comment - perhaps a little harsh but we appreciate your interest. The reference to Mt York in the digital gallery is a typo, it should be Mt Blaxland – which is referred to everywhere as 
“the most westerly point reached by Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson … in 1813”
Brian Fox, “Blue Mountains Geographical Dictionary”
We will correct the typo in the digital gallery.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It's actually not obvious where "Mt Blaxland" actually is.     I just walked across the Blue Mountains.    "Mt Blaxland"  is "somewhere"  west of Cox's River but it doesn't seem to be a very prominent peak.    Mt Blaxland seems to be somewhat south of the village of Rydal,   and would be very close,  if not actually on,  the divide.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Anyhoo,   this photo is certainly of the Mitchell's Pass ( aka Victoria Pass ),  which is the current route of the Great Western Highway between Mount Victoria and Little Hartley.   It is not "Soldiers Pinch".

comment.author: 50415738@N04
comment._content: There is a Mitchell's Pass on the Eastern side of the mountains from Blaxland down to Emu Heights, but this pic is definitely Victoria Pass

comment.author: 97211055@N05
comment._content:
Soldier's Pinch is on an old (now bypassed) section of the highway between Mt.Boyce / Blackheath and Mount Victoria.
Google Maps show it quite well. It was the scene of many truck roll overs and accidents before the bypass was built.
The photo here shows Mount Victoria Pass and it almost looks the same today, even the rock sitting precariously on the cliff in the upper centre section of the photo is still there.

comment.author: 33938248@N06
comment._content: This is a photo of Victoria Pass. Soldier's Pinch is located east of Mt Victoria, as stated above, the old road is bypassed but the new road goes over that "pinch". The main western railway line located just below the road at the location mentioned has always been referred to as "Soldier's". The poster above quoting from a newspaper mentioning about the road deviating near the recreational oval i would say would be referring to Browntown Oval.

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content: Definitely Victoria Pass www.flickr.com/photos/97539983@N07/9609447809/
